Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Rapid stem rust resistance responses in barley; non host resistance mechanisms
Award.AbstractNarration: Understanding genetic resistance of crop plants against microbial pathogens is important for world food security and sustainable agricultural practices. To effectively deploy genetic resistance against important pathogens in crops we must understand the mechanisms underlying the different layers of plant innate immune systems. This project will investigate the stem rust race Ug99 resistance mechanism in barley in order to characterize the underlying molecular pathways and protein interactions mediating resistance against this highly virulent race of stem rust, currently considered a threat to world food security. The investigators will utilize genetic, molecular and biochemical approaches to answer the question of what mechanisms are responsible for resistance and if they have the characteristics of the more durable non-host type of resistance. The function of the genes involved and the timing of the resistance response indicate that the only known Ug99 resistance mechanism in barley, the rpg4/Rpg5 locus, is possibly a remnant of a multilayered non-host resistance mechanism. Thus, the investigators hypothesize that barley is a recent host of wheat stem rust and this pathosystem has not resulted from ancient co-evolution between the pathogen and the host. The investigators expect to elucidate the molecular mechanisms involved in the response and determine if it is an early non-host type of resistance. This information will fill gaps in the limited knowledge of plant innate immune systems and also be utilized to deploy more effective and durable resistance in important cereal crops including wheat and barley. The project will be utilized to recruit and train the next generation of molecular plant pathologists with special emphasis on peoples underrepresented in science, technology, engineering and mathematics. The cutting edge research tools and techniques used in the project and mentoring by the lead investigator will give undergraduate and graduate students an excellent educational opportunity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit During the CAREER award the project outcomesprovided significant progress on the functional analysis of the rpg4/Rpg5-mediated stem rust resistance mechanism. The rpg4/Rpg5-mediated resistance locus (RMRL) is effective against broad races of wheat stem rust in barley including race TTKSK (A.K.A. Ug99), which is considered a threat to world food security because it is virulent on~85% of cultivated wheat varieties and more than 95% barley accessions grown worldwide. The RMRLrepresents an “integrated decoy” immunity receptor that we hypothesize to have evolved to recognize a stem rust pathogen virulence effector, provisionally named Avr4/5. Based on the integrated decoy hypothesis it was speculated thatAvr45evolved tofacilitates the relaxation of stomatal closure and seizure, an early plant defense mechanism, by hijacking the function of the stomata expressed barley protein kinase HvApk1b. The Arabidopsis homolog of HvApk1b, designated AtApk1b, is expressed in stomata and involved in stomata opening in response to light. Thus, the Avr4/5virulence effector manipulation of the HvApk1b gene may trick the cereal host into opening its stomata allowing the pathogen to enter the host at night when the stomata are usually closed, the timing that the rust pathogen evolved to infect the host to avoid desiccation. 

The CAREER grant funding allowed us to redefine RMRLby showing that the genome architecture and predicted functions of the protein domains involved follow the “Integrated Decoy” or “Integrated Sensory Domain” (ISD) model. The data supports the model that the Rpg5 NBS-LRR (NLR) typical immunity receptor with a C-terminal protein kinase (PK) domain with nearly 98% identity to the HvApk1b protein, functions as an NLR-integrated decoy/sensory domain (NLR-ISD). Our genetic and functional analyses of RMRL determined that the translocation of the host virulence effector target, HvApk1b, onto the NLR immunity receptor was facilitated by a putatively directed genome reorganization event. Several classes of ISDs, have been shown to be targeted by a broad taxa of pathogen virulence effectors representing “susceptibility hubs” that are fused to the NLR immunity receptors as diverse “baits” to efficiently “trap” the pathogen in the act of manipulating the susceptibility target to facilitate colonization and inadvertently trip the NLR-mediated immunity responses. However, the Rpg5R-gene at RMRL is the first example of a single NLR immunity receptor that contains two alleles with different ISDs, representing unprecedented allelic variation of an NLR-ISD immunity receptor. Of further interest is that the two Rpg5 ISDs have antagonistic function as all the resistant alleles contain a predicted functional PK ISD and the major class of susceptible alleles contains a predicted functional protein phosphatase 2 C (PP2C) ISD. Interestingly, we recently showed that the PP2C domain negatively regulates the functional Rpg5 PK ISD, thus, conferring the recessive nature of rpg4-mediated resistance. These data suggest that the two putative effector targets have interacting/antagonistic biochemical activities that possibly had ancestral interactions prior to their integration as ISDs. Our most recent data suggests that the rpg5-PP2C alleles actually confer a strong-programmed cell death resistance at the stomata significantly decreasing the number of successful penetrations by the pathogen, but if the pathogen outgrows this response and successfully colonizes the host then there is a rapid development of a compatible interaction (susceptibility). The two independent ISD integration events on the same NLR uniquely positions us to analyze the genome architecture involved in the translocation events to begin characterizing the breakpoints to determine how effector targets are evolutionarily directed for fusion with the NLR immunity receptors as “baits” to “trap” and identify diverse pathogen invaders in plants. This could have broad implications in the understanding of this new paradigm of plant immunity to important pathogens that threaten food security

Broader Impact The CAREER project also made progress towards integrating education and science by making it possible for the PI to acquire the first next generation sequencer in the state of North Dakota. During the life of the grant the PI developed a full scale NGS lab with multiple sequencers that is utilized by multiple disciplines at the University. We utilize the NGS lab to bring next generation sequencing and analysis to undergraduate lab courses at NDSU including Soil Ecology and Microbial Genomics. The funding was also used to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in science with a focus on women and Native Americans. Through the funding the PI was able to recruit a Native American undergraduate student, two female undergraduate students and two female high school students to work on aspects of the CAREER grant. We are also achieving the outreach goal by starting the “Science Outreach and Teaching; Rekindling Indigenous Scientific Curiosity”program that will bring interactive scientific experimentation labs to young Natives Americans starting in the Fall trimester 2018. The materials for developing the teaching packets were developed during the funding period and instrumentation acquired leveraged from other funding sources and donations.
